body:
Yes, I was able to reproduce this issue. I'm guessing the difference is that the rename dialog changes focus from the cells to the field. Therefore, makes sense that  `dd`, `j`, `k`, `a`, etc don't work. In the other modals, there is no such change of focus, so we are still able to modify the cells in command mode.

UPDATE: Actually, the .focus() is intended but for some reason, it is not working. I tried to dismiss the "About IPython" modal pressing Enter and doesn't work.

There's more to it than focus - dialog does explicitly call `keyboard_manager.disable()`:

https://github.com/ipython/ipython/blob/master/IPython/html/static/base/js/dialog.js#L119

Well, there are some inconsistencies. "Edit Notebook Metadata" seems to work okay "always". "Keyboard Shortcuts"  works correctly the first time but after that, the `keyboard_manager` is enabled and the focus is on the cells. "About IPython Notebook" doesn't work correctly in any situation. Can you replicate this in those modals?

Aha, the fact that the same dialog works when launched from the menu gives me a clue. The toolbar uses an action, and the callback for that action does:

``` javascript
env.notebook.restart_kernel();
env.notebook.focus_cell();
```

I guess that the focus_cell() call re-enables the keyboard manager after the dialog is shown. @Carreau, is there a reason we're doing that?

Unfortunately, this doesn't tell me why I'm having focus problems in cite2c, where I don't call focus_cell().
Hmm, thanks for investigating that. I'm hoping @Carreau, @jdfreder or @minrk will chip in, as they're all more familiar with the JS stuff than I am.

Aha, thanks for working that out.

Short term: @Carreau, should we really be calling `register_events` on the whole toolbar? The buttons don't need keyboard focus, and the fact that they get it has led to other bugs. Maybe we should be using `register_events` on the specific elements that need keyboard interaction instead.

Longer term: I've come across a similar issue before, when displaying one dialog immediately after another. The general pattern is that two things are disabling and enabling the keyboard manager in a pattern like this:

```
    ----interaction 1----
disable               enable
    |             |     |                    |
               disable                     enable
                  ---------interaction 2------
```

I think what we need is a mechanism for 're-enable the keyboard manager if I was the last thing to disable it'. One way to implement this would be something like a focus system - so in this case, focus would be transferred from the notebook to the toolbar to the dialog, and once the dialog is focussed the toolbar doesn't put the focus back on the notebook.

Ping @ellisonbg because I recall you worked on the complexities of the keyboard manager stuff.
I've put this on the agenda for tomorrow's dev meeting.

> I guess that the focus_cell() call re-enables the keyboard manager after the dialog is shown. @Carreau, is there a reason we're doing that?

Yes, we had complaint that clicking on button was loosing cell focus. 

So either we do allow button to have focus and tell user they have to click back in input area.
Or we try to fight browser focus in some cases.

> Short term: @Carreau, should we really be calling register_events on the whole toolbar? The buttons don't need keyboard focus, and the fact that they get it has led to other bugs. Maybe we should be using register_events on the specific elements that need keyboard interaction instead.

I'm fine with removing register_events on toolbar. I don't remember the reason. 
I think it might have been for more complex elements like Jon's filter.

> Yes, we had complaint that clicking on button was loosing cell focus. 

I remember that for the save button, but for e.g. restart kernel, where it brings up a dialog, we don't want the cell to be focussed again.
@takluyver the easiest way is to just keep a count of disables, decrement it on enable, and at 0 actually enable.
I thought of that too, though we'd need a way to bypass the counter and force it enabled, because the disable/enable pairs are not completely reliable - see #7565.

Ouch, this stuff is soo painful and difficult. <close eyes and pretend it
just goes away>

I will be at the dev meeting today to talk about this, but in general I
think:
- We should not focus elements. We might even want to remove the tabindex
  from our cell divs to completely get rid of this issue. This would allow us
  to add more intelligent animated scrolling.
- We should try to transition into registering our keyboard shortcuts on
  the notebook div, rather than the whole page. We will have to do this
  anyways when we enable the notebook to be embedded into a phosphor panel.

On Mon, Mar 23, 2015 at 9:52 PM, rsmith31415 notifications@github.com
wrote:

> @takluyver https://github.com/takluyver
> 
> Maybe we should be using register_events on the specific elements that
> need keyboard interaction instead.
> 
> I think that is the best option.
> 
> There is another very simple solution. In toolbar.js:133:
> 
> ```
>         button.attr('data-jupyter-action', action_name);
>         var fun = el.callback|| function(){
>             button.blur();
>             that.actions.call(action_name)
>         };
> ```
> 
> This is forcing blur(); on the buttons before calling the action (in this
> case, restart_kernel). The pattern is the following: enabling the
> keyboard (before modal), disabling the keyboard (when showing the modal),
> enabling the keyboard (after hiding the modal). Since this change applies
> to all the buttons of the toolbar, the pattern is the same.
> 
> By the way, when you say you have seen a similar issue with dialogs, maybe
> that is a different problem because modals are supposed to be removed after
> termination (or equivalently, destroyed after initializing another modal),
> right?
> 
> I don't think focus_cell() is enabling the keyboard. It seems to be
> selecting the cell and applying focus:
> 
> notebook.js:712
> 
> function () {
>     var cell = this.get_selected_cell();
>     if (cell === null) {return;}  // No cell is selected
>     cell.focus_cell();
>  }
> 
> (cell.focus_cell() is simply this.element.focus();) That must be the
> reason why it didn't change anything associated to the keyboard manager
> when I removed that line (after forcing .blur();)
> 
> I remember that for the save button, but for e.g. restart kernel, where it
> brings up a dialog, we don't want the cell to be focused again.
> 
> Uhm, but I believe that is the default behavior in master. I'm assuming
> focus(); only selects a cell in command mode.
> 
> @Carreau https://github.com/Carreau Maybe env.notebook.focus_cell(); is
> not needed anymore because I removed it in the restart_kernel action and
> didn't notice any difference. By the way, I haven't seen issues regarding
> focus after clicking on a button, but if we need to add focus_cell(),
> that shouldn't be a problem.
